data.scenario: Your coworker is running late to an important team presentation. Everyone is ready and waiting. Do you:
data.scene: Inspired by The One Where No One's Ready - When Ross's friends take too long to prepare for an important museum fundraiser, each reacts differently to time pressure and commitment.

options.text: Immediately point out the delay to the team and express frustration about unprofessionalism; insist we start without them
Stay calm and check in with them privately; offer to help them get ready or reschedule if needed
Make jokes about the situation to lighten the mood while continuing to wait; joke with others about the delay
Analyze the situation logically; note what could be improved in the planning process for next time
Feel anxious about the delay and worry this reflects poorly on the whole group; express your concerns about how this looks
Go with the flow without comment; whatever happens, happens; no point stressing about things you can't control

data.scenario: A close friend reveals they're considering a major life decision that conflicts with a plan you two made together. They value your input. How do you respond?
data.scene: Inspired by *The One With Rachel’s Going Away Party* (Season 10, Episode 16), specifically the sequence commonly known as 'Ross Didn’t Get a Goodbye.' Rachel’s decision to move to Paris directly conflicts with the shared, unspoken plan she had with Ross to raise Emma together in New York and remain closely involved in each other’s daily lives. This decision also impacts the entire friend group, who have built their lives around being a constant support system. Monica, deeply affected as Rachel’s closest friend and Emma’s aunt, responds with emotional honesty while ultimately supporting Rachel’s independence, showing maturity by acknowledging how the decision disrupts collective plans yet choosing to prioritize Rachel’s growth and future.

options.text: Express disappointment openly; remind them of the commitment they made and how this affects you personally
Listen deeply and help them explore their options; support whatever choice feels right for them, even if it means changing plans
Make light of it with humor; tell them they're overthinking and suggest going out to discuss over drinks instead
Help them objectively weigh pros and cons; focus on facts and long-term consequences rather than emotions
Feel conflicted and anxious about the whole situation; worry that you're not being a good friend or being too controlling

data.scenario: You're at a restaurant and realize you ended up with a much better meal than your friends, who ordered cheaper food due to budget constraints. Do you:
data.scene: The friends are at a restaurant discussing their orders and the bill. Monica, Ross, and Chandler comfortably order full meals and suggest splitting the check evenly. Joey, Rachel, and Phoebe, who can only afford very cheap items like side salads and water, become visibly uncomfortable. The scene highlights financial imbalance at the table, where some friends clearly have more than others, not because of food quality but because of money.

options.text: Discreetly call the server over on their behalf and insist on a better dish at no charge to them
Offer to trade plates with them so they get your better meal; you're fine eating whatever
Point out loudly that their meal looks bad and make fun of them for ordering something cheap
Say nothing; it's their choice what they order; they'll handle their own satisfaction
Express concern about them getting less for their money; ask if they're having financial trouble and offer to help

data.scenario: A group member shares something very personal and vulnerable during a team meeting. Everyone goes quiet. What do you do?
data.scene: While the group is casually talking at Central Perk, Phoebe unexpectedly mentions that her mother died by suicide. She states it calmly and without seeking sympathy.

options.text: Acknowledge their courage, validate their feelings, and ask thoughtful follow-up questions to show you care
Say something unexpected or bizarre to break the tension and make everyone laugh, even if it's not quite appropriate
Shift the focus away from them; suggest moving on to the next topic to spare them further discomfort
Assess the situation rationally; this is a professional setting and personal matters should be handled outside of work
Feel very uncomfortable; sit in the discomfort while internally worrying about saying the wrong thing

data.scenario: You and a friend have a significant disagreement about values. They want your approval for a choice you think is wrong. Do you:
data.scene: Inspired by *The One Where Heckles Dies* (Season 2, Episode 3). During a group conversation, Phoebe openly states that she does not believe in evolution and challenges Ross’s scientific worldview, calling it just a theory. Phoebe seeks Ross’s acceptance of her belief. Ross, whose identity is strongly tied to science and evidence, becomes deeply conflicted because validating her view feels intellectually dishonest to him. The disagreement creates visible tension and silence within the group. After struggling internally, Ross softens his position and tells Phoebe that while he still believes in evolution, he can accept that there is a tiny possibility he might be wrong. By acknowledging uncertainty rather than insisting on absolute certainty, Ross preserves the friendship while staying true to his core values.

options.text: Clearly state your perspective and why you think they're making a mistake; provide detailed reasoning
Listen to their perspective without judgment; acknowledge their right to choose even if you disagree
Make a joke to deflect from the serious disagreement; avoid getting into a heavy debate
Keep quiet about your disagreement; it's not your place to judge their personal decisions
Feel conflicted and anxious; worry that disagreeing will damage the friendship, but also feel your values are at stake

data.scenario: A colleague asks for your honest feedback on a project they've spent weeks on. You find significant flaws. How do you respond?
data.scene: Inspired by *The One Where Joey Speaks French* (Season 10, Episode 13). Joey asks Phoebe for honest feedback on his French-speaking skills before an important audition he's been preparing for. When Joey demonstrates what he's practiced, Phoebe discovers significant flaws—he's not speaking French at all, just nonsensical sounds. She faces the exact dilemma from your question: how to give honest feedback when a colleague has spent weeks on something that has major problems. Phoebe's response evolves through several stages: First, she tries the gentle approach, attempting to correct him while staying encouraging. However, Joey remains confident he's doing well, so Phoebe escalates to direct honesty: 'You're not speaking French!' This blunt feedback still doesn't fully land because Joey lacks the self-awareness to recognize the depth of the problem. Ultimately, Phoebe balances honesty with compassion—she doesn't let him continue in delusion, but she also protects him from complete humiliation by speaking to the audition director privately in French to soften the blow. The scene teaches that honest feedback is necessary even when it's uncomfortable, but it should be delivered with care for the person's dignity and feelings, especially when they've invested significant time and effort into their work.

options.text: Be direct and detailed about the flaws; provide a comprehensive critique with specific areas for improvement
Start with positives, then gently introduce concerns; soften the feedback so they don't feel discouraged
Offer to work on it together; roll up your sleeves and help them fix the problems yourself
Say it looks fine; don't risk hurting their feelings or starting a conflict over subjective issues
Acknowledge the effort but express concerns; ask clarifying questions to understand their approach better before judging

data.scenario: You witness a friend being treated unfairly by someone in authority. How do you respond?
data.scene: When you witness someone in authority treating your colleague unfairly (like Joanna humiliating Sophie)

options.text: Immediately step in and confront the authority figure; assert that this treatment is unacceptable
Support your friend privately afterward; ask what they need and offer to help them address it formally
Make a witty comment or joke about the situation to defuse the tension and make your friend laugh
Stay quiet; your friend is an adult and can handle their own problems; getting involved might make it worse
Feel anxious about the situation; worry about the potential consequences if you intervene but also feel guilty if you don't

data.scenario: Your friend said something inappropriate. The person laughs but seems uncomfortable. Do you:
data.scene: Jack Geller tells Chandler and Monica to 'go ahead' and be intimate while he guards the door, making them visibly uncomfortable. How would you react if you witnessed this scene?

options.text: Quietly pull your friend aside later and express concern about how the joke landed
Ignore it; they're both laughing, so it's probably fine; you don't want to be the humor police
Immediately make an even bigger, more absurd joke to shift the focus and defuse any awkwardness
Call out the joke in the moment; explain that it was hurtful and that we should all treat each other with more respect
Feel torn about it; be unsure if the joke was inappropriate or if you're overreacting; stay silent but feel uncomfortable

data.scenario: You're asked to help a friend move, but you have other plans. The timing is inconvenient. What do you do?
data.scene: Rachel gifts Monica a night of packing together on their last night as roommates. However, Monica wants to involve everyone else—Chandler, Ross, Joey, and Phoebe—to help with the packing too. The problem is that all the guys already have other plans: Chandler and Joey planned to do nothing together one last time, and Ross claims he has Ben (though he's actually lying). When Phoebe warns them 'Monica's gonna make you pack! She's got jobs for everyone!' they all try to escape out the door to avoid being roped in. Despite their reluctance and existing plans, Monica insists 'everybody has to help!' and eventually guilts them into staying and helping pack. How would you react if Monica asked for your help packing when you already had plans to relax?

options.text: Immediately cancel your plans; your friend needs help and that takes priority
Negotiate; offer to help for a few hours or help them find other people to assist; try to meet them halfway
Make it fun; gather a group of people and turn it into a party; bring drinks and snacks to make it enjoyable
Politely decline; explain your plans are already set and suggest they ask someone else with more availability
Feel guilty about saying no; worry they'll be upset with you; agonize over the decision before reluctantly helping

data.scenario: You discover a friend has been dishonest with you about something important. How do you respond?
data.scene: Ross and Rachel drunkenly get married in Las Vegas. When they sober up, Rachel insists they get an annulment immediately. Ross promises Rachel he'll take care of it. However, Ross is terrified of having three divorces (he was previously divorced from Carol and Emily), so he secretly decides NOT to get the annulment—he lies to Rachel and tells her it's been handled when it hasn't. Ross keeps Rachel in the dark about still being married to her for weeks. Phoebe discovers Ross's lie and confronts him, but Ross asks her not to tell Rachel. Meanwhile, Rachel is preparing to move in with Ross (as roommates) because Monica and Chandler are moving in together. Eventually, Rachel discovers the truth when Ross's divorce lawyer, Russell, calls the apartment looking for Ross. Russell leaves a message saying 'since I haven't heard from him, I assume he's giving the marriage a try.' Rachel answers the phone and realizes Ross lied to her about getting the annulment—they're still legally married. Rachel is absolutely furious. She storms into Ross's university lecture hall and confronts him in front of all his students, yelling at him for lying to her about something so important. How would you respond if you discovered a friend had been dishonest with you about something this significant?

options.text: Confront them directly about the dishonesty; express how disappointed you are and demand an explanation
Listen to their perspective without judgment; try to understand why they felt the need to be dishonest
Make a joke about it to lighten the mood; use humor to address the awkwardness of the situation
Distance yourself from them; you can't trust someone who's been dishonest; the friendship may need to end
Feel hurt and conflicted; worry about the friendship but also about confronting them; avoid bringing it up

data.scenario: You're put in charge of planning an event for your friend group. Everyone has different ideas and expectations. What's your approach?
data.scene: Monica is planning Phoebe's wedding as her Maid of Honor. However, Monica and Phoebe have completely different visions for the event. Phoebe wants a simple, laid-back wedding with her friend Marjorie playing steel drums. Monica, being a control freak, wants an elegant, fancy wedding with ice sculptures, a harpist in white, and non-vegetarian appetizers. Monica completely takes over the planning and makes changes without consulting Phoebe—she even fires Marjorie and replaces her with a harpist because 'steel drums don't really say elegant wedding.' At the rehearsal dinner, Monica rushes Phoebe through her toast ('You're at 2101 and I'm not amused'), changes the vegetarian menu to include pork, and barks orders like a military sergeant with a headset. Phoebe becomes so overwhelmed and frustrated that she fires Monica as her wedding planner. However, when a massive blizzard hits and Phoebe tries to handle everything herself, she quickly realizes how stressful wedding planning is—ice sculptures arrive at the wrong place, she doesn't know technical terms for flowers, and everything starts falling apart. Phoebe eventually swallows her pride and rehires Monica, begging her to be the 'crazy b*tch' again. Monica adapts and gives Phoebe a simple outdoor wedding in the snow, bringing back Marjorie on the steel drums. How would you approach planning an event when everyone in your friend group has different ideas and expectations?

options.text: Take charge; use your organizational skills to create a plan that meets your standards; make all the key decisions
Gather input from everyone; create a collaborative plan that incorporates multiple perspectives and ideas
Keep it casual; plan something fun and low-key; don't overthink it or stress about every detail
Delegate the planning to someone else; analyze what everyone wants and assign tasks accordingly
Feel the pressure to make everyone happy; worry constantly about getting it right; be anxious about the responsibility

data.scenario: A friend asks you to keep a secret that could hurt someone else if revealed. What do you do?
data.scene: Joey discovers his father is having an affair with another woman named Ronni. Joey's dad, Joey Sr., asks Joey to keep this secret and not tell his mother. Joey is torn apart by this request—he loves both his parents and doesn't want to hurt his mother, but his father is begging him to stay silent. Joey carries the weight of this secret, knowing that if his mother finds out, it will devastate her and potentially destroy his parents' marriage. The secret is actively hurting someone (Joey's mother) because she's being lied to and betrayed, even though she doesn't know it yet. Joey struggles with the moral dilemma: should he protect his father by keeping the secret, or should he tell his mother the truth even though it will cause her immense pain? Eventually, Joey's father brings Ronni to Thanksgiving dinner and introduces her as a 'friend,' making Joey even more uncomfortable. Joey finally confronts his father, telling him he needs to end the affair or tell his mother the truth. Joey realizes that keeping this secret is causing harm—his mother deserves to know the truth, even if it's painful. How would you respond if a friend asked you to keep a secret that was actively hurting someone else, even if revealing it would cause pain?

options.text: Promise to keep it secret; their trust in you is paramount
Explain that you can't keep this secret; the person who would be hurt deserves to know; offer to help them tell the truth
Accidentally reveal the secret to someone else (it just slips out); you're not great at keeping secrets anyway
Say nothing; listen without judgment; let them decide what to do; don't get involved in their business
Feel torn between loyalty and ethics; worry about making the wrong choice; agonize over whether to reveal it

data.scenario: You notice someone in your friend group is being excluded or not fitting in. What do you do?
data.scene: Ross, Joey, and Monica play with a ball for hours, refusing to let Chandler join because he's a 'dropper' and will ruin their streak—Chandler stands on the sidelines feeling excluded and hurt, protesting 'I am not a dropper!' but they won't include him. If you were Ross, Joey, or Monica in that moment, how would you react when Chandler asks to join?

options.text: Immediately include them; go out of your way to make them feel comfortable and valued
Subtly suggest to others that they include this person; talk to them privately to see if they need support
Don't get involved; it's not your responsibility to manage everyone's social dynamics
Point out directly to the group that they're excluding this person; call them out on their behavior
Feel uncomfortable and conflicted; worry about getting involved but also feel bad for the excluded person

data.scenario: You and a friend have a misunderstanding that escalates into conflict. How do you handle it?
data.scene: Ross and Rachel fight on their anniversary, and when Rachel says 'maybe we should take a break,' Ross thinks she means break up and sleeps with someone else that night—but Rachel only meant a break from fighting, leading to a devastating conflict over the misunderstanding of what 'a break' actually meant. How would you handle a misunderstanding with a friend that escalates into a major conflict?

options.text: Respond defensively; explain your side loudly and clearly until they understand you were right
Take time to cool down; then approach them calmly to understand their perspective and find common ground
Suggest going out and doing something fun together to move past it; don't dwell on the conflict
Rationally analyze what went wrong; identify the logical errors in their thinking that caused the conflict
Feel hurt and anxious; worry they're upset with you; overthink what you said and how to fix it

data.scenario: Your friend makes a big life decision you don't agree with. They're not asking for permission, just informing you. What do you do?
data.scene: Monica and Chandler decide to move to the suburbs to raise their twins, leaving Manhattan and their iconic apartment behind. When they inform the rest of the friends about their decision, Ross, Rachel, Phoebe, and Joey are shocked and upset that the couple wants to leave Manhattan —they strongly disagree with this life decision. Ross thinks the couple is just trying to get it out of their system and that NYC is the only place to be , essentially dismissing their decision as a phase. The friends try desperately to convince Monica and Chandler to stay by reminiscing about all the wonderful memories they've shared in New York—poker games, power outages, Thanksgiving dinners, and countless moments in their apartments. Monica and Chandler aren't asking for permission or approval; they've already made their decision, found their dream house, and put in an offer. How would you respond if your friend made a big life decision you don't agree with, and they're not asking for permission, just informing you?

options.text: Express your honest opinions about why you think it's a bad idea; provide detailed reasoning
Support their right to make their own choices; trust that they know what's best for themselves
Make a light joke about it; keep the tone friendly and avoid serious criticism
Say nothing; they didn't ask for your opinion, so it's not your place to offer unsolicited judgment
Feel conflicted; want to be supportive but also genuinely worried; express concern cautiously

data.scenario: You discover you've hurt someone unintentionally. How do you respond when they bring it up?
data.scene: Ross accidentally says 'Rachel' instead of 'Emily' during his wedding vows at the altar. Ross has no idea he's even going to say it—it just slips out unintentionally in the middle of the ceremony. When Emily brings it up after the wedding, completely devastated and humiliated, Ross is shocked and tries to apologize repeatedly, insisting it was just a mistake and didn't mean anything. Emily locks herself in the bathroom refusing to accept his apologies, and eventually escapes through the window. Ross has unintentionally hurt Emily in the worst possible way at the worst possible time, and when she confronts him about it, he defensively insists 'We were getting married!' and that it was just a slip of the tongue with no deeper meaning. How would you respond if you discovered you've hurt someone unintentionally and they bring it up?

options.text: Immediately apologize sincerely; take full responsibility and ask how you can make it right
Explain your intention; try to help them see you didn't mean it that way; defend yourself while apologizing
Lighten the mood with humor; apologize in a casual, non-serious way to move past it quickly
Avoid the conversation; it's done, nothing can change it; moving forward is what matters
Feel terrible and anxious; want to make it right but worry you've ruined the relationship forever

data.scenario: Your friend is going through a difficult time emotionally. They haven't explicitly asked for help but seem to be struggling. What do you do?
data.scene: Chandler breaks up with Kathy after discovering she cheated on him, and he's devastated and depressed. He hasn't explicitly asked his friends for help, but Monica, Rachel, and Phoebe notice he's clearly struggling emotionally—he's in the 'sweatpants phase' of grieving, sitting around moping. Instead of waiting for Chandler to ask for support, the girls proactively take him out to a strip club (Phase 2 of Joey's breakup recovery plan) to help him move past his heartbreak, even though this is typically something the guys would do. They recognize Chandler is going through a difficult time and needs help processing his emotions, so they step in without being asked. How would you respond if your friend was going through a difficult time emotionally but hadn't explicitly asked for help?

options.text: Directly ask them if they want to talk; make space for them to open up without judgment
Distract them with fun activities or humor; help them take their mind off their problems temporarily
Subtly show you're there for them; be present without pushing; let them know you're available if they need anything
Don't get involved; they'll handle it themselves or reach out if they really need help
Feel anxious about stepping in; worry you'll say the wrong thing or make it worse; hesitate to help

data.scenario: You're asked to choose between a personal opportunity and your friend's needs. Both require your attention at the same time. What do you do?
data.scene: Joey gives up eating meat—something he genuinely loves—so Phoebe can eat it guilt-free during her surrogate pregnancy, making a purely selfless sacrifice with no benefit to himself.

options.text: Cancel the personal opportunity; your friend's needs come first, always
Negotiate; try to find a way to meet both your need and theirs; ask them if they can compromise on timing
Take the opportunity for yourself; you can't always put others first; it's okay to prioritize your own goals
Analyze the situation logically; determine which outcome has greater overall value and act accordingly
Feel torn; worry that whatever you choose, someone will be hurt or disappointed; agonize over the decision

data.scenario: Someone new joins your friend group and seems like they might be a good match with one of your friends romantically. Do you:
data.scene: Phoebe and Rachel notice someone new who seems perfect for Joey and, without being asked, try to set him up because they believe they know what’s best for his love life.

options.text: Immediately try to set them up; orchestrate meetings and create romantic moments between them
Mention it gently to your friend; see if there's mutual interest before doing anything else
Don't say anything; let them figure it out naturally; relationships happen when they're meant to
Warn your friend to be cautious; assess whether the new person is trustworthy and right for them first
Feel enthusiastic but also anxious; want to help but worry about interfering or making a mistake

data.scenario: You're invited to something your friend group is doing, but you're not close with most of the people attending. You feel like an outsider in the group dynamic. What do you do?
data.scene: Ross joins Emily’s rugby group, tries to fit in despite feeling out of place, and ends up embarrassed and hurt.

options.text: Go and try to fit in; make an extra effort to connect with people and be part of the group
Go but stay more reserved; let others drive the conversation while you observe and participate when appropriate
Decline politely; you're not comfortable and would rather spend time with people you're closer to
Ask your closest friend if they'll stick by your side; agree to go if you can be their partner in the group
Feel anxious and self-conscious about attending; worry about being judged or not fitting in; hesitate about the commitment
